bibl.title: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, December 22, 1922

div1.p: Frost sends Carter information on the lectures Carter will deliver at Johns Hopkins University.

div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, December 22, 1922
div1.opener:
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
310-312 WEST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD. December 22, 1922.
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
Dr. Henry R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I am very sorry indeed that I have not found an
opportunity to see you as I had promised and expected.

Since I had your letter consenting to give the
two lectures on the epidemiology of yellow fever I have
been to Washington two or three times, but each time on
some special business at the Bureau which has taken up the
whole day; and in the meantime I have had to go to Cin-
cinnati and have had various engagements here which have
prevented me coming to Washington especially to see you.

I hope that I may be able to get over there next
week; if not, then sometime soon thereafter; but in the
meantime I am sending you an outline of our proposed
course of lectures as at present arranged. The schedule
of lectures is subject to change as regards date to fit
the convenience of the lecturers, since it makes no great
difference in what sequence the different topics are taken
up.

As to the scope of the lectures, since they are to
be given by a number of different lecturers, it will ob-
viously be quite impossible to have them cast on a uniform
plan or from any uniform viewpoint; and I do not think
it even desirable that they should be in any sense “stand-
ardized.” What seems to me of more importance is that each
one who gives a lecture should be quite free to give, in
such order as seems to him best, the facts and conclusions
which he thinks of most importance for an understanding of
the disease in question.

The general outline which Dr. Freeman, Dr. Doull
and I are following in our lectures is given in the enclosed
outline. I am not presuming to send you this as even a
suggestion to you for your own lectures, but merely as
being perhaps of interest to you in showing about what the
scope of our own lectures will be, and also to invite any
suggestions you may have for a better sequence and scope.

With cordial regards to yourself and Miss Laura,
and best wishes for Christmas and the New Year,
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, W. H. Frost. WHP:G
